title: A God's Wife of Amun
description:
The female figure wears a vulture headdress over a striated wig; broad collar; and a sheath reaching to the ankles. 
Condition: Right arm broken off just above elbow; greenish brown patina; several hair line fractures in the surface.
credit_line: Gifts in memory of Christos G. Bastis and Charles Edwin Wilbour Fund
section: The Third Intermediate Period & the Beginning of the Late Period

museum_location.name: 19th Dynasty to Roman Period, Martha A. and Robert S. Rubin Gallery, 3rd Floor

completeness.description: All data has been vetted. Objects generally have quality photos and descriptions.

labels.content: This figure's heavy wig bears traces of the vulture headdress with cobra worn by royal women, goddesses, and God's Wives of Amun. Because very few bronzes of God's Wives of Amun are known, identification is difficult. Scholars have attributed the statue to priestesses ranging in date from Shepenwepet I of the Libyan-Egyptian Dynasty XXIII to Shepenwepet II of the Nubian Dynasty XXV. The Dynasty XXIII dating is unlikely.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art
